text:
This will be the century
of the life sciences.

We're seeing an explosion of new
scientific ideas and companies
based on these ideas.

These new companies are
using deep knowledge

of cells and cellular
machinery to make medicines.

We see it with regenerative
medicine with mRNA companies,
with cell therapies.

And the hope is that
for the first time,

we might be able to talk
about curing disease and not
just treating it.

I study four forces
behind this phenomenon.

The role of public
funding of science

in creating these
ideas, capital markets

in seeding these nascent
ventures, pricing and insurance

coverage for ensuring
incentives and access,

and regulation for
approving these medicines.

Much of this innovation happens
in a tiny set of cities.

So we need to understand these
crucibles of innovation too.

Together, these forces
shaped the science

that comes out of the
great academic labs,

and makes it the medicines
that we use as patients.
